In a space with the Besicovitch property, any set `s` can be covered with balls whose measures
add up to at most `Œº s + Œµ`, for any positive `Œµ`. This works even if one restricts the set of
allowed radii around a point `x` to a set `f x` which accumulates at `0`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite Œº] [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.Measure.OuterRegular Œº] {Œµ : ENNReal},
  Œµ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ (f : Œ± ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù) (s : Set Œ±),
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, Set.Nonempty (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥)) ‚Üí
        ‚àÉ t r,
          Set.Countable t ‚àß
            t ‚äÜ s ‚àß
              (‚àÄ x ‚àà t, r x ‚àà f x) ‚àß
                s ‚äÜ ‚ãÉ x ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall x (r x) ‚àß ‚àë' (x : ‚Üët), ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (Metric.closedBall (‚Üëx) (r ‚Üëx)) ‚â§ ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº s + Œµ
name: Besicovitch.exists_closedBall_covering_tsum_measure_le
docString:
In a space with the Besicovitch property, any set `s` can be covered with balls whose measures
add up to at most `Œº s + Œµ`, for any positive `Œµ`. This works even if one restricts the set of
allowed radii around a point `x` to a set `f x` which accumulates at `0`.

A pseudometric space is second countable if for every positive real `Œµ`, there exists a countable `Œµ`-dense set.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Œ±],
  (‚àÄ Œµ > 0, ‚àÉ s, s.Countable ‚àß ‚àÄ (x : Œ±), ‚àÉ y ‚àà s, dist x y ‚â§ Œµ) ‚Üí SecondCountableTopology Œ±
name: Metric.secondCountable_of_almost_dense_set
docString: A pseudometric space is second countable if for every positive real `Œµ`, there exists a countable `Œµ`-dense set.

This is the **Measurable Besicovitch Covering Theorem**. It postulates the following: consider a set `s` in a metric space with a second countable topology, a measurable space, an open measurable space, and the Besicovitch covering property. For each point `x` in `s`, we are given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with radii belonging to a set `f` of real numbers and being arbitrarily small. If the underlying measure `Œº` of this space is finite, then there exists a countable set `t` such that:
- Every pair `(p.1, p.2)` from `t` satisfies `p.1` belongs to `s`, `p.2` belongs to `f(p.1)`, and `p` describes a closed ball in the metric space.
- The set `t` is pairwise disjoint, meaning no two different closed balls in `t` intersect.
- The measure of the set difference between `s` and the union of all closed balls described in `t` is zero. In other words, almost all of `s` is covered by these closed balls.

This theorem is particularly applicable to normed real vector spaces that possess the Besicovitch covering property.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasure Œº] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù) (s : Set Œ±),
  (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥).Nonempty) ‚Üí
    ‚àÉ t,
      t.Countable ‚àß
        (‚àÄ p ‚àà t, p.1 ‚àà s) ‚àß
          (‚àÄ p ‚àà t, p.2 ‚àà f p.1) ‚àß
            ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (s \ ‚ãÉ p ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2) = 0 ‚àß t.PairwiseDisjoint fun p => Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2
name: Besicovitch.exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae_of_finiteMeasure_aux
docString:
This is the **Measurable Besicovitch Covering Theorem**. It postulates the following: consider a set `s` in a metric space with a second countable topology, a measurable space, an open measurable space, and the Besicovitch covering property. For each point `x` in `s`, we are given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with radii belonging to a set `f` of real numbers and being arbitrarily small. If the underlying measure `Œº` of this space is finite, then there exists a countable set `t` such that:
- Every pair `(p.1, p.2)` from `t` satisfies `p.1` belongs to `s`, `p.2` belongs to `f(p.1)`, and `p` describes a closed ball in the metric space.
- The set `t` is pairwise disjoint, meaning no two different closed balls in `t` intersect.
- The measure of the set difference between `s` and the union of all closed balls described in `t` is zero. In other words, almost all of `s` is covered by these closed balls.

This theorem is particularly applicable to normed real vector spaces that possess the Besicovitch covering property.

A pseudometric space is second countable if, for every `Œµ > 0`, there is a countable set which
is `Œµ`-dense.

type:

docString:
A pseudometric space is second countable if, for every `Œµ > 0`, there is a countable set which

A set of natural numbers has Schnirelmann density equal to 1 if and only if it contains all positive natural numbers.

type: ‚àÄ {A : Set ‚Ñï} [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ‚àà A], schnirelmannDensity A = 1 ‚Üî {0}·∂ú ‚äÜ A
name: schnirelmannDensity_eq_one_iff
docString: A set of natural numbers has Schnirelmann density equal to 1 if and only if it contains all positive natural numbers.

The theorem named `eventually_residual_liouville` states that the set of Liouville numbers is a residual set. In other words, the set of Liouville numbers, which are real numbers `x` such that for every natural number `n`, there exist integers `a` and `b` with `1 < b` such that `0 < |x - a/b| < 1/b^n`, includes a countable intersection of dense open sets in the real number topological space.

type: ‚àÄ·∂† (x : ‚Ñù) in residual ‚Ñù, Liouville x
name: eventually_residual_liouville
docString: The theorem named `eventually_residual_liouville` states that the set of Liouville numbers is a residual set. In other words, the set of Liouville numbers, which are real numbers `x` such that for every natural number `n`, there exist integers `a` and `b` with `1 < b` such that `0 < |x - a/b| < 1/b^n`, includes a countable intersection of dense open sets in the real number topological space.

The center of mass of a finite subset of a convex set belongs to the set
provided that all weights are non-negative, and the total weight is positive.

type:

name: Convex.centerMass_mem
docString:
The center of mass of a finite subset of a convex set belongs to the set

The **measurable Besicovitch covering theorem**. Assume that, for any `x` in a set `s`,
one is given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with arbitrarily small radii.
Then there exists a disjoint covering of almost all `s` by admissible closed balls centered at some
points of `s`.
This version requires that the underlying measure is finite, and that the space has the Besicovitch
covering property (which is satisfied for instance by normed real vector spaces). It expresses the
conclusion in a slightly awkward form (with a subset of `Œ± √ó ‚Ñù`) coming from the proof technique.
For a version assuming that the measure is sigma-finite,
see `exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae_aux`.
For a version giving the conclusion in a nicer form, see `exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasure Œº] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù) (s : Set Œ±),
  (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, Set.Nonempty (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥)) ‚Üí
    ‚àÉ t,
      Set.Countable t ‚àß
        (‚àÄ p ‚àà t, p.1 ‚àà s) ‚àß
          (‚àÄ p ‚àà t, p.2 ‚àà f p.1) ‚àß
            ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (s \ ‚ãÉ p ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2) = 0 ‚àß Set.PairwiseDisjoint t fun p => Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2
name: Besicovitch.exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae_of_finiteMeasure_aux
docString:
The **measurable Besicovitch covering theorem**. Assume that, for any `x` in a set `s`,
one is given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with arbitrarily small radii.
Then there exists a disjoint covering of almost all `s` by admissible closed balls centered at some
points of `s`.
This version requires that the underlying measure is finite, and that the space has the Besicovitch
covering property (which is satisfied for instance by normed real vector spaces). It expresses the

For a version assuming that the measure is sigma-finite,

For a version giving the conclusion in a nicer form, see `exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae`.

A map between two inner product spaces is a conformal map if and only if it preserves inner
products up to a scalar factor, i.e., there exists a positive `c : ‚Ñù` such that
`‚ü™f u, f v‚ü´ = c * ‚ü™u, v‚ü´` for all `u`, `v`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} {F : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup F]

  IsConformalMap f ‚Üî ‚àÉ c, 0 < c ‚àß ‚àÄ (u v : E), ‚ü™f u, f v‚ü´_‚Ñù = c * ‚ü™u, v‚ü´_‚Ñù
name: isConformalMap_iff
docString:
A map between two inner product spaces is a conformal map if and only if it preserves inner

If there are subsets which are `Œµ‚ÇÅ`-dense and `Œµ‚ÇÉ`-dense in two spaces, and
isometric up to `Œµ‚ÇÇ`, then the Gromov-Hausdorff distance between the spaces is bounded by
`Œµ‚ÇÅ + Œµ‚ÇÇ/2 + Œµ‚ÇÉ`.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u} [inst : MetricSpace X] [inst_1 : CompactSpace X] [inst_2 : Nonempty X] {Y : Type v}

  (‚àÄ (x : X), ‚àÉ y ‚àà s, dist x y ‚â§ Œµ‚ÇÅ) ‚Üí

      (‚àÄ (x y : ‚Üës), |dist x y - dist (Œ¶ x) (Œ¶ y)| ‚â§ Œµ‚ÇÇ) ‚Üí GromovHausdorff.ghDist X Y ‚â§ Œµ‚ÇÅ + Œµ‚ÇÇ / 2 + Œµ‚ÇÉ
name: GromovHausdorff.ghDist_le_of_approx_subsets
docString:
If there are subsets which are `Œµ‚ÇÅ`-dense and `Œµ‚ÇÉ`-dense in two spaces, and

Riemann-Lebesgue lemma for functions on a real inner-product space: the integral
`‚à´ v, exp (-2 * œÄ * ‚ü™w, v‚ü´ * I) ‚Ä¢ f v` tends to 0 as `w ‚Üí ‚àû`.

type:

The measurable Besicovitch covering theorem. Assume that, for any `x` in a set `s`,
one is given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with arbitrarily small radii.
Then there exists a disjoint covering of almost all `s` by admissible closed balls centered at some
points of `s`.
This version requires that the underlying measure is sigma-finite, and that the space has the
Besicovitch covering property (which is satisfied for instance by normed real vector spaces).
It expresses the conclusion in a slightly awkward form (with a subset of `Œ± √ó ‚Ñù`) coming from the
proof technique.
For a version giving the conclusion in a nicer form, see `exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]

  (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, Set.Nonempty (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥)) ‚Üí
    ‚àÉ t,
      Set.Countable t ‚àß
        (‚àÄ p ‚àà t, p.1 ‚àà s) ‚àß
          (‚àÄ p ‚àà t, p.2 ‚àà f p.1) ‚àß
            ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (s \ ‚ãÉ p ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2) = 0 ‚àß Set.PairwiseDisjoint t fun p => Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2
name: Besicovitch.exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae_aux
docString:
The measurable Besicovitch covering theorem. Assume that, for any `x` in a set `s`,
one is given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with arbitrarily small radii.
Then there exists a disjoint covering of almost all `s` by admissible closed balls centered at some
points of `s`.
This version requires that the underlying measure is sigma-finite, and that the space has the

It expresses the conclusion in a slightly awkward form (with a subset of `Œ± √ó ‚Ñù`) coming from the

For a version giving the conclusion in a nicer form, see `exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae`.

The measurable Besicovitch covering theorem. Assume that, for any `x` in a set `s`,
one is given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with arbitrarily small radii.
Then there exists a disjoint covering of almost all `s` by admissible closed balls centered at some
points of `s`. We can even require that the radius at `x` is bounded by a given function `R x`.
(Take `R = 1` if you don't need this additional feature).
This version requires that the underlying measure is sigma-finite, and that the space has the
Besicovitch covering property (which is satisfied for instance by normed real vector spaces).

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology Œ±] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite Œº] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù) (s : Set Œ±),
  (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, ‚àÄ Œ¥ > 0, Set.Nonempty (f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 Œ¥)) ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ (R : Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, 0 < R x) ‚Üí
        ‚àÉ t r,
          Set.Countable t ‚àß
            t ‚äÜ s ‚àß
              (‚àÄ x ‚àà t, r x ‚àà f x ‚à© Set.Ioo 0 (R x)) ‚àß
                ‚Üë‚ÜëŒº (s \ ‚ãÉ x ‚àà t, Metric.closedBall x (r x)) = 0 ‚àß
                  Set.PairwiseDisjoint t fun x => Metric.closedBall x (r x)
name: Besicovitch.exists_disjoint_closedBall_covering_ae
docString:
The measurable Besicovitch covering theorem. Assume that, for any `x` in a set `s`,
one is given a set of admissible closed balls centered at `x`, with arbitrarily small radii.
Then there exists a disjoint covering of almost all `s` by admissible closed balls centered at some
points of `s`. We can even require that the radius at `x` is bounded by a given function `R x`.
(Take `R = 1` if you don't need this additional feature).
This version requires that the underlying measure is sigma-finite, and that the space has the
Besicovitch covering property (which is satisfied for instance by normed real vector spaces).

If there exists a sequence of compact closed balls with the same center
such that the radii tend to infinity, then the space is proper.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] {Œ≤ : Type u_3} {l : Filter Œ≤} [inst_1 : Filter.NeBot l] {x : Œ±} {r : Œ≤ ‚Üí ‚Ñù},

name: ProperSpace.of_seq_closedBall
docString:
If there exists a sequence of compact closed balls with the same center
such that the radii tend to infinity, then the space is proper.

Every separable metric space embeds isometrically in `‚Ñì^‚àû(‚Ñï)`.
